Después de un rato, uno de ellos se levantó y dijo que iba a buscar algo en la cocina, y me dejó solo con el otro, que se puso a tocar un piano antiguo que había en un rincón de la habitación. La música era hermosa y me sentí transportado a un mundo de ensueño, donde todo parecía perfecto y sin problemas. Pero de repente, el viento comenzó a soplar con más fuerza y la música se interrumpió. El dueño de la casa regresó con una sonrisa en el rostro y me dijo que iba a mostrarme algo en el jardín. El dueño de la casa se detuvo en el umbral y me dijo que me esperara un momento, y desapareció en la oscuridad. en_results_raw: The only completely stationary object in the room was an enormous couch on which two young women were buoyed up as though upon an anchored balloon. They were both in white, and their dresses were rippling and fluttering as if they had just been blown back in after a short flight around the house. I must have stood there for a few moments, transfixed by the surreal scene before me, before I finally managed to tear my gaze away from the pair and take in the rest of the room. The walls were adorned with an assortment of peculiar objects, each one more out of place than the last. There was a vintage typewriter perched on a shelf, next to a stack of dusty old books and a taxidermied owl. A grandfather clock ticked away in the corner, its face a deep, rich brown that seemed to glow in the dim light. The air was thick with the scent of old books and dust, and I could feel the weight of years of history bearing down upon me. As I took a step forward, the two women on the couch suddenly sat up, their eyes locking onto mine with an unnerving intensity. They regarded me for a moment, their faces expressionless, before one of them spoke in a voice that was both melodious and unsettling. "Welcome to our home," she said, her words dripping with an otherworldly sweetness. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I replied, my voice barely above a whisper, "Thank you." The woman's smile was like a ray of sunshine, but it only served to make me feel more uneasy. I took another step forward, my eyes scanning the room for any sign of a door, but there was none. The walls seemed to stretch on forever, with no visible exit in sight. I was trapped, and I knew it. The woman's smile grew wider, and I could feel her eyes boring into my very soul. I tried to speak, but my voice caught in my throat. The woman's companion, who had been silent until now, spoke up, her voice a low, husky whisper. "Don't worry, dear," she said. "You'll get used to it here. We'll show you the ropes." I swallowed hard, trying to find my voice, but it was no use. The two women began to laugh, their laughter like the tinkling of wind chimes on a summer breeze. It was a sound that was both beautiful and terrifying, and I knew that I was in for a long and strange night.

es_results_raw: de la estatua de la Libertad, que parecía una joya en la oscuridad de la noche. Mi amiga, que había estado callada durante todo el viaje, se inclinó hacia adelante y le dijo: "Queremos ir al Greenwich Village". El taxista asintió con la cabeza y se metió en el tráfico de la calle Ciento cincuenta y ocho, mientras que yo miraba por la ventana y veía las luces de la ciudad pasar a toda velocidad. es_results_raw: el 15 de mayo de 1922. Es un día soleado y caluroso, y el sol comienza a ponerse sobre el horizonte cuando llego a la estación de trenes. Me siento un poco nervioso mientras espero a que llegue el tren de las 5:15. Miro a mi alrededor y veo a varias personas que parecen estar esperando a alguien. Algunas están sentadas en bancos, mientras que otras están de pie, mirando el reloj. Me pregunto quién será el destino de todos estos viajeros. ¿Serán como yo, con un corazón lleno de esperanza y un espíritu de aventura? O tal vez sean personas que regresan a casa después de una larga ausencia, con historias que contar y secretos que guardar. El tren comienza a llegar, y la gente comienza a moverse hacia la plataforma. Me siento un poco más nervioso, ya que sé que pronto veré a Gatsby. ¿Qué aspecto tendrá? ¿Será como me lo imaginé? ¿O será alguien completamente diferente? Me acerco a la plataforma y veo a Gatsby esperando a alguien. Está de pie, con su sombrero en la mano y una sonrisa en su rostro. Me siento un poco sorprendido, ya que no me esperaba que fuera tan... tan... elegante. Pero entonces, veo a la persona que espera a Gatsby, y mi corazón comienza a latir con más fuerza. Es Daisy Buchanan, la mujer que Gatsby ama. Está de pie, con su vestido blanco y su sombrero de seda. Parece tan hermosa y elegante, que me siento un poco avergonzado por mi propia apariencia. Pero Gatsby no parece notar mi presencia, ya que está completamente absorto en la conversación con Daisy. Me siento un poco incómodo, ya que no quiero interrumpir su momento, pero al mismo tiempo, no puedo evitar mirar a Daisy. ¿Qué es lo que siente Gatsby al verla? ¿Es amor, o es algo más? Me pregunto si alguna vez podré entender el misterio que rodea a Gatsby y su relación con Daisy. El tren comienza a moverse, y la gente comienza a subir a bordo. Gatsby y Daisy se despiden, y Gatsby se vuelve hacia mí. Me sonríe y me dice: «¿Qué tal si nos unimos a ellos?». Me siento un poco sorprendido, pero acepto su invitación. Subimos al tren y nos sentamos en un asiento cerca de la ventana. El tren comienza a moverse, y nos alejamos de la estación. Me siento un poco emocionado, ya que no sé qué nos espera en el futuro. Pero estoy seguro de que con Gatsby, cualquier cosa puede suceder.

En su lugar, se limitó a señalar hacia la calle principal, donde una multitud de personas se había reunido en torno a algo. She went with a slightly older crowd—when she went with anyone at all. Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go
en_second_half: to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas. She was effectually prevented, but she wasn’t on speaking terms with her family for several weeks. en_results_raw: to leave for New York, how she had been seen arguing with her father in the garden, and how she had been spotted dancing with a young man at a party in the village. I didn't pay much attention to these stories, but I did notice that Daisy seemed to be growing more and more distant, and I couldn't help but wonder if there was any truth to the whispers. As the summer drew to a close, I found myself thinking about her more and more, and I began to feel a pang of regret for not being able to spend more time with her. I tried to brush off these feelings, telling myself that I was too young to be getting involved in anything serious, but the truth was that I couldn't shake the feeling that I was missing out on something special. It wasn't until the following spring, when I received an invitation to a party at the Buchanans', that I saw Daisy again, and I was struck by how different she looked - her eyes seemed brighter, her smile more radiant, and her laughter more carefree. I was immediately drawn to her, and I found myself wondering if maybe, just maybe, I had been wrong to let her slip away. As I watched her across the room, I felt a spark of attraction that I couldn't ignore, and I knew that I had to find a way to get to know her better. Little did I know, that chance encounter would change everything, and set me on a path that would lead me to places I never could have imagined.

en_first_half: Instead of taking the shortcut along the Sound we went down to the road and entered by the big postern. With enchanting murmurs Daisy admired this aspect or that of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling odour of jonquils and
en_second_half: the frothy odour of hawthorn and plum blossoms and the pale gold odour of kiss-me-at-the-gate. It was strange to reach the marble steps and find no stir of bright dresses in and out the door, and hear no sound but bird voices in the trees.
en_results: The sun-kissed stone walls, the vibrant hues of the blooming flowers, and the soft rustle of the trees swaying in the gentle breeze all captivated her senses. As they strolled along the winding path, the sweet fragrance of the jonquils wafted
en_results_raw: The sun-kissed stone walls, the vibrant hues of the blooming flowers, and the soft rustle of the trees swaying in the gentle breeze all captivated her senses. As they strolled along the winding path, the sweet fragrance of the jonquils wafted through the air, mingling with the scent of freshly cut grass and the distant hint of the sea. The sound of birdsong filled the air, a chorus of melodies that seemed to dance on the wind, and Daisy felt her heart lift with joy. She couldn't help but feel a sense of wonder at the beauty of this place, a feeling that seemed to grow with every step she took. The postern gates, once a simple entrance, now seemed like a threshold to a world of enchantment, a world that was full of magic and possibility. As they walked, the trees grew taller, their branches intertwining above them like a verdant canopy, casting dappled shadows on the ground below. The air was filled with the soft chirping of crickets and the occasional distant rumble of a carriage, a reminder that they were not alone in this idyllic scene. Despite the tranquility of their surroundings, Daisy couldn't shake the feeling that they were being watched, that unblinking eyes were trained on them from the shadows. She glanced around, but saw nothing out of the ordinary, just the usual assortment of garden statues and topiaries. Still, the feeling persisted, and she found herself glancing over her shoulder, half-expecting to see a figure emerging from the trees. But there was never anyone there, and she was left to wonder if she had simply imagined the whole thing. As they continued on their way, the path began to wind and twist, leading them deeper into the heart of the estate. The trees grew closer together here, their branches forming a tunnel of leaves and flowers that filtered the sunlight, casting the air in a soft, emerald green glow. The sound of running water grew louder, and Daisy's heart quickened with excitement as she realized they were approaching a small pond. The water was crystal clear, reflecting the sky above like a perfect mirror. A small wooden bridge spanned the pond, its boards weathered to a soft silver gray. Daisy felt a sense of peace wash over her as she gazed out at the serene scene before her. It was as if the world had slowed down, and all that existed was this moment, this perfect, peaceful moment. She felt a hand on her arm, and turned to see her companion smiling at her. "Shall we cross the bridge?" he asked, his eyes sparkling with mischief. Daisy nodded, and together they stepped out onto the weathered boards, the sound of the water rushing beneath them like a gentle melody. As they reached the middle of the bridge, Daisy felt a sense of freedom, of release, as if she had left all her worries behind. She closed her eyes, letting the sun shine down on her face, and breathed in deeply, feeling the peace and tranquility of the moment wash over her. When she opened her eyes again, she saw that they had reached the other side of the pond, and were standing in a small clearing surrounded by a ring of tall trees. The air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers, and the sound of birdsong seemed to come from all directions. It was as if they had entered a different world, a world of beauty and wonder. Daisy felt a sense of awe wash over her, and she turned to her companion with a smile. "This is incredible," she breathed. Her companion smiled back, his eyes shining with pleasure. "I'm glad you like it," he said. "I was hoping you would." And with that, he took her hand, and together they walked into the heart of the clearing, surrounded by the beauty and magic of the estate.

They stood there for a moment, the only sound being the soft crunch of leaves beneath their feet. They had been together for a long time, but in this moment, it felt like they were two strangers who had just met, the world around them melting away. The man took a step closer, his hand reaching out to brush a strand of hair behind her ear, and the woman's heart skipped a beat as she felt the gentle touch. It was as if time had stood still, and all that existed was the two of them, suspended in this moment of perfect connection. The world around them was alive with possibility, and they both knew that this night was going to be one they would never forget. As they stood there, the moon continued its slow descent in the sky, casting an ethereal glow over the scene, and the leaves continued to fall, swirling around them like a gentle dance. The air was filled with an almost palpable sense of magic, and they both felt it, a sense of being on the cusp of something new, something exciting, something that would change the course of their lives forever. The man's eyes never left hers, and the woman's heart was racing with anticipation, her soul yearning for what was to come. And in that moment, they both knew that they were exactly where they were meant to be, in this place, at this time, with each other. The world around them was full of uncertainty, but in this moment, they were certain of one thing: they were meant to be together, and nothing could ever change that.

La habitación se convirtió en un vacío, y solo quedamos los dos, suspendidos en un momento de profundo silencio. I took a deep breath and launched into the story, leaving out no details, and Meyer listened intently, his silence a palpable thing that seemed to vibrate through the phone line. When I finished, he let out a low whistle, and I could almost hear the wheels turning in his head as he weighed his options. "I think I can help you out, kid," he said finally, his voice dripping with a false sense of sincerity, and I felt a surge of hope rise up inside me, only to be quickly tempered by the cold, hard reality of the situation.

The silence was oppressive, a heavy blanket that wrapped around him, making it hard to breathe. He took a deep breath, trying to shake off the feeling, but it lingered, a nagging sense of melancholy that he couldn't shake. He looked around the room again, taking in the details, the way the sunlight streamed through the window, casting a warm glow on the dust motes that danced in the air. It was a moment of perfect stillness, a moment of perfect clarity, and in that moment, he felt the weight of his years, the accumulation of all the joys and sorrows, the triumphs and failures, the loves and losses. en_results_raw: completion>  fate to tidy up after me. I walked back to the old house, the one where I had grown up, and made my way to the attic. The air was thick with dust and the smell of decay, and cobwebs clung to my face as I climbed the creaky stairs. I had avoided this place for years, ever since the argument with my father, but now I had to face it. The trunk in the corner, the one with the rusty lock, was the first thing I saw. I had left it untouched since the day I moved out, and now I felt a pang of guilt for not dealing with it sooner. I knelt down, my hands trembling slightly as I fumbled for the key in my pocket. The key was old and worn, but it still turned smoothly in the lock. The trunk creaked open, revealing a jumble of old clothes, letters, and photographs. I rummaged through the contents, my heart heavy with memories. There were letters from my mother, written in a handwriting I had almost forgotten, and photographs of my childhood, smiling and carefree. But there was one thing that caught my eye, a small, leather-bound book with a strange symbol embossed on the cover. I opened it, and the pages were filled with my father's handwriting, a mixture of poetry and prose that spoke of a deep sadness and longing. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I read the words, and I knew that I had to understand the story behind this book. I sat there for a long time, lost in the words, trying to make sense of the past. The sun was setting outside, casting a golden glow over the attic, and I felt a sense of peace wash over me. I knew that I had to leave, but I also knew that I would never forget this moment, this connection to my past. I closed the book, and with a sense of resolution, I locked the trunk and headed back downstairs, ready to face whatever lay ahead.

es_results_raw: de la casa de mis sueños me lo hiciera por mí. Así que me dirigí a la habitación que había estado evitando durante días, la que contenía recuerdos de mi pasado y la causa de mi partida. Me senté en la cama, rodeado de fotos y objetos que me recordaban a ella, y comencé a ordenar y a deshacerme de todo lo que me recordara a aquella relación fallida. Era un proceso doloroso, pero sabía que era necesario para poder seguir adelante y dejar atrás el dolor y la tristeza que me había causado.
